George Orwell really was unambiguously to the left. The problem is that we nowadays tend to see socialism/left-wing politics as really state centered. A lot of Americans even have the misconception that socialism = "whatever the government does". That's of course not was socialism is. Back to Orwell: he belonged to the libertarian/non-statist branch of socialism (which includes most forms of anarchism), as opposed to the authoritarian branch (USSR, etc.). Orwell sympathized with the anarchists in revolutionary spain, and he himself favored a truly socialist society but with a lot of respect for individual liberty and democratic principles.

In the decades since the publication of Nineteen Eighty-Four, there have been numerous comparisons to Aldous Huxley's novel Brave New World, which had been published 17 years earlier, in 1932.

They are both predictions of societies dominated by a central government and are both based on extensions of the trends of their times.

However, members of the ruling class of Nineteen Eighty-Four use brutal force, torture and mind control to keep individuals in line, while rulers in Brave New World keep the citizens in line by addictive drugs and pleasurable distractions.

In October 1949, after reading Nineteen Eighty-Four, Huxley sent a letter to Orwell and wrote that it would be more efficient for rulers to stay in power by the softer touch by allowing citizens to self-seek pleasure to control them rather than brute force and to allow a false sense of freedom:

"Within the next generation I believe that the world's rulers will discover that infant conditioning and narco-hypnosis are more efficient, as instruments of government, than clubs and prisons, and that the lust for power can be just as completely satisfied by suggesting people into loving their servitude as by flogging and kicking them into obedience."

Elements of both novels can be seen in modern-day societies, with Huxley's vision being more dominant in the West and Orwell's vision more prevalent with dictators in ex-communist countries, as is pointed out in essays that compare the two novels, including Huxley's own Brave New World Revisited.

Comparisons with other dystopian novels like The Handmaid's Tale, Virtual Light, The Private Eye and The Children of Men have also been drawn.

This is a really interesting point. I've lived in Japan for the better part of a decade, and while here I've come across quite a few expressions in Japanese which simply don't have equivalences in English. One example is: "お疲れ様でした。(Otsukaresamadeshita)" It's said in a number of different situations, but the most common are after finishing work or after doing something strenuous. The closest phrase in English I can think of would be: "Good job," but it doesn't convey the same meaning, which is something more along the lines of: "You worked hard and I appreciate your dedication, so try to take a good rest from now."

Actually, the reason the left or right can't claim Orwell is because there's more to a political spectrum than just left and right. Political compass is correct in putting four sectors: Authoritarian left, Authoritarian right, Libertarian right, and libertarian left.

Orwell was a Libertarian left individual. That's why he opposes capitalism(he is on the left) but also opposed the traditional communism(authoritarian left). He is on record as praising Revolutionary Catalonia during the Spanish Civil war, which was an anarcho-syndicalist society(libertarian left).

So, actually, the left can claim Orwell. At least, the libertarian left can. He is never found criticizing the libertarian left, but you can find him criticizing all of the other sectors. It's not unusual for a libertarian left individual to criticize the authoritarian left.

So I always thought that the relationship between language and thought in 1984 was really interesting, and I was taking a linguistics course and there's actually a whole linguistic theory sort of based around it called the "Sapir-whorf hypothesis" and this kind of theory basically says that language determines thought, one example they give is the Hopi tribe not having words for time (and then according to the hypothesis also not having the capacity to speak about time), however on further investigation the Hopi have metaphors and units for time, just not ones that maybe have direct English translations. There's also people who have aphasia and have lost the ability to communicate or understand language, but who still are able to have thoughts, or human babies who understand the concept of math and number or develop facial associations before they are able to form linguistic based thoughts. The point of all this is, is that though oppressive governments can restrict language and suppress freedoms by limiting communication capacity through language, language and thought might not be as deterministic as Sapir and Whor thought. In other words there's hope that the capacity for human experience does and will always to some extent subvert the oppressions of a big brother type government.

I understand the need to not go into too much detail in these videos, but there's no need to get socialism completely wrong either. I'm not a socialist, but I feel it necessary to accurately describe socialism if we're to understand Orwell.

In short, socialism is nothing but an economic idea that sees the tools of production—company computers, tractors, production lines in factories, etc— used to make things owned by the workers, instead of shareholders.

Socialism has many different flavours. In one socialist school of thought, workers may work in co-operatives, where they democratically decide what to do with the tools they own. You know, how much of what to produce, how much to sell them for – that sort of thing. Socialism can also use the markets, much like in capitalism. For example, supply and demand may be used to decide on prices for things we buy, just like in capitalism today. The only difference in this socialist school of thought from capitalism would be that instead of shareholders owning businesses, the workers working for those businesses own them.

So no, socialism isn't a safety net or universal healthcare. That's just a safety net. Social democrats, who are *capitalists*, tend to push for better safety nets. So Sweden and Norway tend to have social democratic platforms, not socialist platforms.

He wasn't anti-communism; he supported anarcho-sydicalist and libertarian marxist in catalonia, both advocate communism in the way Marx saw it which was inspired by Commune de Paris (The Paris Commune). Communism if they stick to the foundation of communism (including anarchist) advocate for the abolition of state in favor of loose coalition of communes using direct democracy & workers' controlled enterprise (Workers' co-ops) which may or may not have socialist markets (Mutualist advocate for some form of communistic market as well as a form of commune bank for taking care of resources in a democratic manner). It isn't that it forbids what caps call "free trade" it is that kind of trading becomes obsolete in favor of the form of the market. Many communist support workers' control not state (As they aim to dismantle unjustified hierarchy); state control and nationalisation while helps with building the means of production aren't socialist and fall under state cap or social corporatism ("Scandinavia model") & you would have a hard time to convince that the USSR was socialist in anything but name when talking with a libertarian commie (we call USSR supporters tankies btw). When I say libertarian communist it includes 3 supergroups being: Anarchist, Marxist Orthodox Libertarians, & Marx derived such as Luxembougism; in reality there is a lot of overlap and they main differ in what order to work in but all work towards the same goals.

C-Vocabulary is used by the cosmetics industry to restrict the understanding of their product ingredients... the most famous of these being the primary ingredient in shampoos: "Aqua" which is a cosmetic industry word for "water".
In Chemistry this word would be "Dihydrogen Monoxide" which fits in with their standardised nonmeclature, however, Chemists tend to desire the free flow of information for developing greater knowledge and so will use the word "water".
There is thus a strong difference between the Chemical and Cosmetics industry. With the cosmetics industry being an example of what occurs when an entity tries to use language to control thought by using unique and non-standardised names for chemicals, and the Chemical industry is an example of the free flow of information by using a standardised and easily understandable naming system.

A good example of this standardised system at work is the transfer of Chemical naming systems into modern language to replace older non-standardised names. "Milk of Magnesia" is something most of the younger generations have no idea of... they know it as "magnesium hydroxide". This is good becasue it clearly explains what the substance is made of.

I don't think there are any thoughts you aren't thinking because of language.

Any functional language will have a basic layer of vocabulary for simple concepts, 'up' 'down'' 'slow' 'fast' 'move' 'person' etcetera. and no matter how many words you remove, if the language remains at all functional, it should be able to express every potential idea, it will just be more or less difficult to do.

Picture a version of the English language that contains a word for 'move' but not a word for run, this wouldn't keep you from thinking about running right? you would just think about it as fast-moving rather than 'running', additional syllables yes, but removed concepts no.

Now lets imagine that same language, but lets imagine that it evolved on a planet that never had birds or bats or bugs or any kind of flying creature, and as a result they never developed a word for 'flying', and then one day someone sees a bird. would they be able to describe it?

Yes. 'non-person thing fast-moving while not on ground', again, much more complicated than just saying 'flying thing' but no more excluded from expression or thought.

Even things that previously had never been even conceptually thought about, like Magnetism, Neutrons, Hadrons, Evolution, Microwave Radiation, etcetera, all can be described using (many) simple words, if simple-words become to long or complicated you could resort to metaphors to explain it, and once it was explained to someone you could name a new simple-word to describe it to them, maybe you start calling magnetism 'broogle' since you have no other word and don't want to go through the effort every time.

Such actions are a natural part of human nature, and if you want to avoid it you have to actively suppress it.

Which, of course, is exactly what happens in 1984. But since that is not what has happened thus far in real life we can assume there are no concepts we are excluded from knowing because of language, even if some might be harder to grasp initially. (note that this DOES only affect initial understanding, since once you understand it you can just invent new words to describe each component part, making the whole thing easier to understand).

To be frank, this is the first time I have (without YouTube's "encouragement") clicked on and watched an entire episode of Crash Course Literature. It was a delightful decision to make but it raises the question - why did I avoid them in the first place?

Bear with me for a moment, it's after all 2 in the morning and my thoughts are as clear as a cloudy sky.

I believe to enjoy art, regardless of its type, origin, presentation, etc. , it doesn't take much if any effort. It's there, it exists, I can blankly stare at it and receive pleasure. It doesn't have to be an involved activity. This can be extrapolated to all areas of life. We can always stay at the sidelines but will get something in return, whether it will be a slight ray of hope or a tear rolling down our eye. It doesn't have to be an involved activity. It doesn't.

So, if we don't seemingly obtain anything extra when we bring ourselves to our life, why ever waste any time on anything, the thinking goes, at least it did for me. What is the point of ever going through the efforts?

I'm on the verge of adulthood, just 22 days until my legal transformation into a responsible part of society, which is why (probably, talking objectively about your current thoughts is bound to failure) I feel lost at times. I don't know what lies ahead and whether I will like it or not. You can say it's the same for everyone but interrupting people is considered rude so keep your comments for the end. As I was saying, the future scares me, and in the lack-of-control way. I might be choosing the wrong occupation. I might be cutting relationships I will later regret. I might be closing myself into a box labeled "Your entirety" and leaving at that. And if the previous, although possibly unrelated paragraphs are to be trusted, my interests cannot give me the tool to escape this situation. Fin.

As I discovered recently, though, conflicting thoughts in your limited skull can cause severe existential anxiety but can also lead to epiphanies. I am studying quite a bit for the national exam in my mother tongue, Bulgarian, which was the reason I have read more about literature than actual works of literature. During this, however, I discovered an interesting side to myself - I enjoy analysing works of literature. Connecting content with ideas through metaphors and similes (I'd use more precise terminology if I had a translation dictionary by my side and a desire to spend extra time on this lengthy post) is my fortè. The more time I spent reading up, the more I understood not only about a particular piece of writing but also about the time period itself. And let me tell you, modernism in the post liberation period of Bulgarian literature didn't seem all that exciting until it became thrilling.

That is the link between all the points up until now and the very reason this video sparked such a thought. I brought myself to literature and it became much more rewarding than it ever had been in the 12 years of formal education I've had. That was the cause of my discomfort whenever I saw a Crash Course Literature, past horrible experience with literature in general. All it took was effort, and the rest came by itself.

Please please please do not forget the propaganda and counter-propaganda that he did working at the BBC, and that most of his writing was autobiographical allegories. The book is framed as a futuristic dystopia, but is about the world he saw around him everyday. For example, when Winston changing past articles for the paper of record in 1948, that was most likely something that Orwell knew or believed was occurring during 1947 and 1948 when he was working at Tribune, The Observer and the Manchester Evening News. Also, you confused the modern concept of "Socialized ___" with Socialism - Socialism is specifically about "the community" owning control of means of production, distribution, and exchange. Capitalism is about private ownership of the aforementioned; and Communism is about public (aka. government) ownership thereof.

It seems that John Green only understands politics on the left-right axis and not also in the context of the libertarian-authoritarian axis. This is illustrated by his statement "It's not quite accurate for the contemporary left or right to claim George Orwell". Orwell was anti-capitalist, a leftist standpoint, and also anti-authoritarian, a libertarian standpoint. This, then would reasonably mean that Orwell was a libertarian leftist. Libertarian leftism, to no one's surprise, is still leftism.

Conveniently, Green in his very next sentence conflates communism with authoritarianism while alluding to the fact that Orwell was opposed to Stalin's USSR. Understandably, this misstep was most likely fueled by the cultural conditioning the US has been exposed to since the 1950s which tells you that communism is authoritarian and that Stalin is the face of communism. Now, a passing knowledge of communism will tell you that this isn't the case, unfortunately in the US there is much more misinformation than education about the topic of communism. Communism requires the abolishment of the state (very obviously anti-authoritarian), the workers of society to control the means of production and not employers or the state (meaning the factories, the tools, how things are distributed, etc.), and horizontal democracy along with the elimination of profit motives in favor of need-based production. As we can plainly see by looking at the actions of Stalin's USSR rather than by what it claimed itself to be, we can see that never gave it's citizens the means of production and that it always remained an undemocratic, totalitarian state. That is the complete inverse of communism. Stalin never sought to provide for the needs of his citizenry, his goal was to establish Russia as a super power via uniting the country as a machine focused on competing with the rest of the world. That isn't communism. At best, that's nationalism. Perhaps that is why Orwell himself stated that the USSR was not leftist, but right-wing.

I'm thinking that, if Newspeak failed, it's possible that the party failed. What I've always wondered is how? O'Brien says to Winston that there is no way in which the Party can be overthrown, and looking at Winston's analysis of it--that the Proles cannot rise up until they have become conscious, but cannot because conscious until they have risen up--one would be tempted to agree with O'Brien. Unless the Inner Party itself fell from within? Not the Outer Party: they're the hands, not the brain, but the Inner Party. That would be next to impossible in my view, though, because those in the Inner Party are insane with their own power. As Goldstein's book says, "The more intelligent, the less sane."
